content.description: Sit start, and use opposing sidepulls. Climb up and left to top out.
content.protection: 2 pads - this has an uneven landing.

content.description: Stand start behind the tree where there is a groove of sorts. Follow the groove seam up and finish up the slab. The crux is getting established for the slab.
content.location: It is to the left of the graffiti right behind the tree.

content.description: Do you like to climb with using more than just your hands and feet? Do you love to grovel and practice offwidth-ish like movements? Do you like to feel like you are Thanksgiving stuffing in the turkey? Then this climb is for you! Sit start all the way back of Panther Cave where the roof crack comes down to the ground. Climb out, grovel a bit, and top out.
content.location: Start all the way back in the throat of Panther Cave where the roof crack goes all the way down to the ground. Sit down, find good hands and a block for your right foot, and start there.

content.description: Sit start under the small overhang below Classic Panther. Get a right hand on a good undercling, and a left hand on the ridge/rail that ascends to the right. Move up along the rail/ridge, over the bulge, and onto the face. Join the finish of Classic Panther.
content.location: Sit start under the small overhang beneath the finishing slab of Classic Panther.

content.description: This is just long enough to blur the line between bouldering and soloing. It is a good slab problem with a few true friction moves before the top and is good for laps, but a fall would be a cheesegrater to the bottom. Â This doesn't look like there's a good way to set up a toprope, otherwise it would be a good problem for kids.
content.protection: A pad may do some good.
content.location: Left of the Panther Cave where the rock protrudes by the tree, start from the lowest point possible, and go straight up.

content.description: Sit start with the two decent holds as indicated in the pic. Throw for jugs, and trend right to top out.
content.location: It is on the boulder that makes up the right side of the cave entrance that has a graffiti that says "Mark" on it.

content.description: Sit start on crimps and sidepulls, and pop to the top. Finish straight up.
content.location: From the main Panther Cave area, walk left about 30 feet to another cave entrance. This climbs the short left face.

content.description: Climb the left side of the first cave entrance you see from the path. The line follows the weakness that trends to the right and tops out on the face above. Slopers, crimps, and edges lead to jugs with an exposed topout.
content.location: Start at the left end of the left face of the first cave entrance seen from Red Cross Path. Sit start on some low ledges, move up-right to slopers, and continue onto the face traversing up and right to some jugs and an exposed face topout.

content.description: This uses the same start as Panther Mark, except it goes left and traverses into the Panther Rock. Bump your left hand out, and sweep your right leg around to gain an awesome toe cam. Work the crack left to reach out to a nice crimp. Bump left again to a decent nub. Stay right, and top out. It is a super fun problem.
These are a large pile of boulders that forms a cave system. They are popular with day hikers as a resting place. There are a handful of nice lines on the west side of the crag.
